Completion Prompts: Capture one insight from today to share with your team.
Identify one small change you can make to align better with customer needs.
Choose one action to improve your sales process based on field insights.

Algorithm.Description: Aligns sales stages with customer decision journeys (stage alignment).

Overall Outcomes.Excellent: You build the process from field data and customer realities → The future creates predictable, high-quality conversions.
Overall Outcomes.Expected: You incorporate some field insights but inconsistently → The future sees uneven performance.
Overall Outcomes.Poor: You design sales steps in isolation from customer reality → The future risks low adoption and conversion.
Overall Outcomes.Transcendent: Field alignment is embedded in sales culture—processes adapt quickly to market shifts → The future sustains strong, resilient sales performance.

Overall Purpose: To design a sales process that matches real customer contexts, needs, and decision-making patterns in the field.

Guiding Questions: What do field insights reveal about our current process?
How aligned are our stages to the real customer journey?
What will we measure to know this process is working?
Themes.Name: Capturing Field Insights Systematically

Excellent.Present pattern: Regular, structured feedback loop in place.

Expected.Example moves: Taking notes during rare field visits.

Poor.Present pattern: No structured feedback from the field.

Transcendent.Edge condition: Insights reviewed before every process update.
Transcendent.Future effect: The future sustains resilient sales performance.
Transcendent.Present pattern: Field insights are embedded in continuous improvement.

Themes.Purpose of This Theme: Gather structured, ongoing feedback from sales reps and customers.
Themes.Why This Matters: Without systematic insight gathering, process changes rely on guesswork.

Guiding Questions: How do customers typically discover our products or services?
What factors influence customers' decisions at each stage of their journey?
Which channels are most effective in guiding customers through their decision-making process?
Themes.Name: Mapping the Customer Decision Journey

Excellent.Present pattern: Journey mapped for all key customer segments.
Excellent.Signals: Actions tailored to stage and segment.

Expected.Example moves: Using enterprise journey for SMB buyers.
Expected.Present pattern: Journey mapped for some customer types only.

Poor.Edge condition: Assume all buyers follow same path.
Poor.Future effect: The future risks low close rates.

Transcendent.30-90 day system effect: Alignment remains strong as markets shift.
Transcendent.Edge condition: Customer journey data integrated with CRM.
Transcendent.Future effect: The future sustains strong sales performance.
Transcendent.Present pattern: Journey mapping is dynamic and updated in real time.

Themes.Purpose of This Theme: Understand and document the actual steps customers take before buying.
Themes.Why This Matters: Misaligned processes push too early or miss key decision points.

Guiding Questions: How do our current sales stages reflect the actual customer journey in the field?
What adjustments are necessary to ensure our sales stages align with field realities?
Which sales stage is most frequently misaligned with field experiences, and why?
Themes.Name: Aligning Sales Stages to Field Reality

Excellent.Present pattern: Stages co-designed with reps and validated in the field.

Expected.Present pattern: Some stages reflect field reality but others don't.

Poor.Example moves: Forcing 5 stages on a 2-step buying cycle.
Poor.Present pattern: Sales stages designed without field input.

Transcendent.Future effect: The future sustains resilient sales performance.
Transcendent.Present pattern: Stage alignment is ongoing and responsive.

Themes.Purpose of This Theme: Ensure sales process stages match what actually happens in the field.
Themes.Why This Matters: Misaligned stages confuse reps and create friction for customers.

Guiding Questions: How can we assess the current skill levels of our team to identify training needs for tool adoption?
What strategies can we implement to ensure seamless integration of new tools into existing workflows?
To what extent are our current training programs effective in promoting the adoption of new tools?
Themes.Name: Integrating Tools and Training for Adoption

Excellent.Present pattern: Integrated tools and role-based training provided.

Expected.Present pattern: Basic training provided but tools not optimized.

Poor.Example moves: Sharing PDF of process and nothing else.

Transcendent.Future effect: The future sustains resilient sales performance.
Transcendent.Present pattern: Adoption supported by culture, coaching, and continuous enablement.

Themes.Purpose of This Theme: Equip reps with the right tools and training to use the process effectively.
Themes.Why This Matters: Even the best-designed process fails without adoption.

Guiding Questions: What patterns or trends have emerged from the results?
How can we leverage the insights gained to improve our strategy?
To what extent do the results align with our initial objectives?
Themes.Name: Reviewing and Iterating Based on Results

Excellent.Present pattern: Process metrics tracked and tied to regular reviews.

Expected.Example moves: Looking at win rate once a year.
Expected.Present pattern: Some metrics tracked but not tied to improvements.

Poor.Edge condition: Assume process is fine unless broken.

Transcendent.Future effect: The future sustains resilient sales performance.
Transcendent.Present pattern: Measurement and iteration embedded in culture.

Themes.Purpose of This Theme: Measure performance of the sales process and refine it regularly.
Themes.Why This Matters: Processes stagnate without measurement and iteration.

Title: Building a Field-Aligned Sales Process
When To Use This Protocol: Use when creating or refining the sales process, entering new markets, or after significant feedback from field reps or customers.
Why This Matters: A sales process disconnected from the realities of customer behavior leads to wasted effort, poor conversion, and missed opportunities. Field alignment ensures relevance, trust, and efficiency.
